Grant.Action: Steps out of the plane calmly with the air of a man who takes nothing seriously, indicating controlled confidence while maintaining a cover.
Turns to help Jan Benes out of the plane, showing attentiveness and readiness to assist an important colleague.
Allows the Man to wipe off the lipstick smudge on his cheek without complaint or resistance, showing trust and tolerance.
Questions the Man politely about being woken up and the situation, showing a friendly and sincere attitude despite confusion.
Accepts being left alone in the car without protest or panic, indicating a measure of patience and trust in others.
Gets dressed quickly after being abruptly awakened and remains coherent enough to engage in light banter despite confusion.
Accepts being left alone in a strange location without questioning or challenging the instruction.
Maintains composure despite being confused about the situation and the secrecy around it.
Follows procedures and moves compliantly with the M.P., gets out of the car on command, presents I.D. card when requested, and remains observant of surroundings.
Appears mystified when left alone in the car, suggesting some momentary confusion or uncertainty.
Greets General Carter warmly and engages in concerned conversation about Benes's condition.
Recognizes and addresses General Carter promptly, recalling his previous encounter and the Pentagon context.
Shows awareness and concern about Benes's condition by asking direct, pertinent questions.
Follows Carter without hesitation after being told the urgency of the situation.
Expresses doubt about his own abilities, saying 'I can't even put a Band-Aid on my finger.' and 'What can I do? Except maybe pass out?'
Follows Carter without objection despite uncertainty and confusion.
Questions the risk of trusting Duval for security purposes, showing concern for safety and skepticism about potential disloyalty.
Accepts orders respectfully from Dr. Michaels without argument.
Expresses uncertainty about Duval's intentions, indicating a cautious and thoughtful attitude rather than blind trust.
Asks clarifying questions about the security risks and suspects surgical assassination, showing engagement and understanding of the stakes.
Questions the decision to include Duval due to doubts about his loyalty or intentions, demonstrating critical thinking and caution.
Acknowledges orders from Dr. Michaels without hesitation, displaying discipline and readiness to comply with command structure.
Expresses uncertainty about Duval's motivations (not sure if he is trying to save or kill), which could indicate lack of information or incomplete judgment.
Jokes about the meaning of <CMDF> with playful sarcasm.
Shows polite curiosity and interest by asking questions about the technology.
Does not display dismissiveness or rudeness when learning about the miniaturization process.
Jokes about the <CMDF> acronym, showing ease and lightness in a tense situation.
Asks for clarification on the acronym when he doesn't understand.
Responds with silent whistle when told about the shrinking technology, showing appreciation and understanding of its significance.
Expresses concern about the Other Side obtaining the technology, indicating awareness of risks involved.
Uses humor and informal remarks rather than technical questions or assessments, which might suggest a less technical approach.
Expresses strong reluctance and fear about being miniaturized and going on the mission, politely asks Carter to reconsider his choice.
Initially bewildered and resistant, but does not show rudeness or hostility toward Carter or the mission.
Expresses strong reluctance and doubt about being miniaturized for the mission, requests reconsideration of his involvement.
Verbally questions the plan and his role, showing awareness of the dangers and the need for suitability.
Shakes hands with Michaels, being polite and professional at first meeting.
Addresses Duval with recognition and respect by acknowledging he has heard of him.
Introduces Colonel Reid and Dr. Duval politely and professionally; shakes hands with Michaels confidently at their first meeting.
Passively observes heated argument without intervening or attempting to mediate.
Greets Miss Peterson with charm and friendly tone.
Engages Captain Owens with light humor to ease tension ('That makes two of us').
Is described by Carter as uniquely qualified for the mission, bringing specialized expertise as a Communications Expert and former Frogman, and being invaluable if anything goes wrong.
Engages in light banter with Captain Owens ('Out of your element, aren't you?'), showing social ease but not necessarily competence relevant to the mission.
Expresses concern about the operational conditions of the miniaturized submarine, showing careful thought and consideration for the crew's safety.
Questions the feasibility of miniaturizing the submarine due to the speed of the circulatory system, showing critical thinking and awareness of physical challenges.
Makes a light-hearted remark about the size being 'all in a day's work,' showing confidence and nonchalance.
Asks practical questions about the mission to understand and prepare, showing concern for safety.
Expresses worry about potential threats by asking about 'attack' in a serious tone.
Asks pertinent questions about how the position of the sub will be tracked and about potential threats.
Does not show misunderstanding or hesitation when faced with complex explanations, indicating attentive and thoughtful engagement.
Attempts levity with a joke about where to get a cab after a serious discussion but is ignored.
Ponders aloud, 'How much can a man give to his country?' showing a reflective and sincere side.
Attempts levity by asking where to get a cab after a serious discussion, failing to engage meaningfully with the concerns raised.
Shows reflection or solemnity with the question 'How much can a man give to his country?' indicating thoughtful awareness.
Starts to help Cora over the threshold, then grins when she tells him not to touch her.
Starts to help Cora over the threshold in the Sterilization Corridor, but respects her wish not to be touched.
Waves Cora to precede him and calmly boards the Proteus last, showing orderly and confident leadership.
Carefully climbs the steps and enters the hatch without hesitation, indicating calm and skillful behavior.
Accepts responsibility of holding the lead box containing the atomic fuel without complaint.
Expresses concern about the danger of atomic fuel but does not show fear or panic, calmly discussing the situation.
Engages Owens in respectful and friendly dialogue, showing interest and admiration for the submarine.
Takes the lead box from Owens carefully and listens to the explanation about the radioactive atomic fuel, asking insightful questions about its function and expressing a cautious understanding.
Shows some skepticism by noting 'That's cutting it mighty close -- for a perfect fit,' indicating critical thinking about the technical feasibility.
Makes a light, admiring remark about the craft ('All in all, quite a canoe...') after technical discussion, demonstrating confidence and ease in the situation.
Lightly jokes by asking to be reminded about the love life of an octopus, showing playfulness and an attempt to connect with others.
Notices and logs that Miss Peterson smiled, implying awareness and a positive recognition of others' emotions.
Begins tapping out a message on the wireless promptly, demonstrating initiative and engagement with communications.
Makes a lighthearted remark about asking the love life of an octopus, showing ease but not directly reflecting competence.
Moves through the lab area attentively, engages in light conversation with Cora showing awareness of the situation.
Makes a somewhat humorous but realistic remark about the difficulty of being shrunk.
Makes a teasing, playful comment to Cora about her skills and warns about the danger of the laser beam.
Engages in friendly conversation with Cora, showing interest in her background and career.
Listens thoughtfully to the wireless message and promptly announces 'Prepare for Miniaturization' loudly enough for all.
Engages in light banter with Cora, showing ease and social intelligence but no direct demonstration of technical skill in this excerpt.
Begins putting on safety harness quickly and correctly along with Duval.
Responds promptly to Owens' call by tapping out message confirming readiness.
Reacts quite convinced seeing the Miniaturizer for the first time and glances at colleagues for confirmation.
Observes the miniaturization process with a moment of wonder and subjective realization.
Calmly reacts to the dangerous fast descent and water landing of the submersible, maintaining composure throughout a potentially suicidal drop.
No panic or signs of confusion when the Proteus 'hits' the water and rocks harshly, implying steady presence of mind.
Watches Duval covertly while working at his valve.
Reassures Michaels by saying 'You'll feel better once we're underway.'
Responds promptly to Owens' command, moves quickly to open Valve One, watches Duval covertly while working, then closes valves when ordered.
Reassures Michaels who is panicking, attempting to calm him despite the stressful situation.
Helps Michaels with his harness after Michaels admits to claustrophobia and asks for forgiveness.
Helps Michaels with his harness calmly, showing attentiveness and steady support in a tense situation.
Taps out a reply to confirm Proteus' status after full reduction, communicating effectively under tense conditions.
Takes down the incoming message efficiently and announces readiness for injection clearly and confidently.
Asks clarifying questions about the concept of Inner Space, showing intellectual engagement and curiosity.
Expresses awe and surprise at the biological environment, indicating openness to new knowledge.
Makes a casual, somewhat humorous comment ('Quite a piece of plumbing') about the circulatory system, showing a relaxed but knowledgeable attitude.
Responds appropriately to hazardous situation, turns to Michaels for guidance.
Exchanges startled looks with Cora, holds onto stanchions for support during strong vibrations but does not take visible control actions or offer solutions.
Grabs Cora and moves quickly to help her toward her seat, attempts to assist her into the harness during dangerous whirlpool conditions.
Reaches out to Cora desperately to help her during the whirlpool's centrifugal force, showing concern and trying to support her physically despite extreme danger.
Commands the crew to strap in immediately upon spotting the whirlpool and tries to help Cora into her seat quickly despite heavy buffeting.
Despite intense physical forces, he manages to grab a stanchion to hold on and attempts to reach Cora on the floor.
The craft is out of his control and whatever averted collision had nothing to do with his steering attempt, showing lack of control in critical moments.
Grabs Cora's waist to prevent her from being flung against the bulkhead, holding onto her with great effort despite the centrifugal force.
Helps Cora rise after ordeal, assesses it is safe to let go of her.
Sees the sub is level and moving slower after difficult current before taking action.
Asks clarifying question about 'Arterio-Venous Fistula' indicating some lack of initial knowledge.
Seeks alternative route when told they cannot go back, showing problem-solving and proactive thinking.
Shows hesitation and reluctance to give up on the mission, saying 'If there's any chance --'
Reluctantly moves to request removal of the craft as ordered when mission seems impossible.
Expresses frustration at the deadlock situation (can't go forward or back) but follows orders without hesitation.
No direct actions or statements by Grant in the excerpt; omission to engage in critical decision-making is noted.
Reads the critical message about stopping the Heart by electric shock clearly and precisely to the team.
Shares amazement with others about the phenomena outside the submarine, engaging collaboratively.
Observes and comments thoughtfully on the complex pulmonary artery structure and blood cell color change.
Expresses amazement and curiosity about the biological process he observes, engages openly with Duval and Cora in a shared moment of wonder.
Responds quickly and attentively to Owens' urgent command, moves promptly to check the pressure gauges, and takes over controls without hesitation.
Passes by Duval and Cora, who are concerned about the leak, without any noted interaction or reassurance.
Suggests using a snorkel tube through the wall to get air without harming Benes.
Notifies Cora about the loose laser, prompting her to check it carefully without blame.
Questions Cora about the laser cautiously, without accusations or hostility.
Leads the team to put on gear quickly after noticing a problem; exchanges looks showing concern but tries to move forward efficiently.
Motivates Michaels to overcome his fear and enter the small escape hatch despite his phobia.
Puts the group's practical needs ahead of responding to wireless communication, showing focus rather than warmth.
Checks Michaels' breather pack carefully before proceeding, showing attention to detail and responsibility.
Decides not to answer the wireless tapping, prioritizing getting air over communication, demonstrating good judgment under pressure.
Encourages the fearful Michaels to proceed into the escape hatch, showing leadership and confidence.
Operates the valve to fill the escape hatch with liquid and unlocks the ventral hatch, displaying technical skill and calmness.
Leads the way swimming out of the hatch and signals Owens to proceed.
Offers to hold the snorkel from the other side of the alveolar wall to overcome pressure challenges, despite warnings about danger.

Takes initiative to continue the mission despite the unexpected strong pressure that pushes the snorkel out, quickly proposes a plan to hold the snorkel from the other side while coordinating with the team, insists on tying his safety line for security.
Expresses surprise at the force of the pressure pushing the snorkel out, indicating some lack of anticipation of environmental conditions.
Takes initiative to secure safety line and pushes through entrance despite danger.
Takes out his safety line, hooks it onto his suit, and communicates effectively with the team to coordinate pushing the snorkel through the alveolus entrance despite high pressure.
Holds firmly against the enormous wind pressure inside the alveolus, showing physical and mental endurance under extreme conditions.
Lets go of the snorkel promptly when the indicator hits full and tries to get out despite the dangerous wind
Struggles and is vulnerable due to the harsh environment, but fights to climb back using the rope
Snakes his safety line around a big rock while fighting a gale.
Waits out the howling tornado before acting quickly to move through the crevice.
Thrusts himself through a crevice just as another breath begins, showing good timing and awareness.
Encourages finding a solution despite the broken laser; tries to think of alternatives; shows concern for continuing the mission.
Suggests carrying spare parts and immediately thinks of a way to improvise a solution by piecing together a broken transistor, confidently asserting he has a source for parts.
Pushes forward with problem-solving when others express doubt, showing initiative and practical thinking.
Chooses to cannibalize the wireless communications equipment to repair the laser and save Benes' life despite the risk of cutting off communication with the outside.
Identifies a critical fix by cannibalizing one little transistor and a circuit wire to repair the laser.
Decides to dismantle the wireless despite warnings about losing communications, showing confidence and prioritizing mission-critical actions.
Explains that radar tracking will still allow them to be located even without wireless comms, demonstrating technical understanding.
Exchanges looks with Michaels, then turns away without comment.
Leads the way to the bow and makes a friendly, calming remark comparing the view to the sea at dawn.
Acknowledges the difficulties of the mission and expresses hope.
Expresses suspicion about possible sabotage and doubts Duval's innocence.
Shares concerns quietly with Michaels, avoiding confrontation in front of others.
Acknowledges uncertainty about others' intentions, showing tolerance.
Points out the suspicious nature of the laser and safety line tampering, demonstrates awareness of potential sabotage, discusses concerns calmly with Michaels.
Expresses skepticism about accidents happening twice in a row, showing critical thinking and caution.
Checks the Minute Recorder and calculates remaining time, showing attentiveness to mission timing.
Reacting with amazement at the sight of the lymphatic duct walls, showing curiosity and observational skill.
Expresses curiosity and admits a lack of knowledge about the lymphatic system.
Reacts to damage caused by the sub to delicate fibers with concern and attention.
Expresses a puzzled comment about the lymphatic system, showing curiosity but also limited prior knowledge.
Observes broken lymphatic fibers drifting and becoming entangled around the bow windows and reacts attentively.
Comments on the situation with a metaphorical statement: 'Looks like somebody declared war.'
Observes and compares the antibody and bacterium interaction as 'Like hand-in-glove.'
Asks if there is an alternate safer route to avoid danger, showing concern for the team's safety.
Points out that enemies are tracking them and may take precautions, indicating awareness and responsibility towards group safety.
Stands beside Michaels reviewing the chart while others deal with a critical situation, indicating calm presence but no direct action or leadership shown.
Shows concern by asking what's wrong when the ship touches bottom.
Responds calmly and practically to a problem, volunteering to go out and clear the clog despite danger.
Nods and respects the team's assessments and advice, indicating cooperation and trustworthiness.
Does not dismiss Cora's anxiety, allowing her to express concern without rebuke.
Humorously comments on the clogged vents needing a lawnmower, lightening the mood.
Recognizes the problem immediately and prepares to address clogged intake vents by gearing up and going outside to fix it despite danger.
Acknowledges the potential danger from Antibodies but proceeds confidently with the task after assessing risk.
Makes a lighthearted but relevant comment ('I could use a lawnmower') showing situational awareness and understanding of the problem scale.
Estimates the time required to clear the clog realistically, demonstrating practical judgment.
Pulls seaweed-like fibers out of the intake vents, working fast at an endless task.
Welcomes Michaels and Cora to join him in yanking out clinging tendrils, working together quickly.
Pulls seaweed-like fibers out of intake vents quickly and persistently despite the task seeming endless.
Works at an exhausting pace with Cora and Michaels to pull out clumps of long fibers from the vents on the Proteus hull, showing sustained effort and focus.
Flung in one direction due to external force without any indication of regaining control or acting skillfully afterwards.
Immediately responds to Cora's call for help, actively searches for her location, and communicates reassurance.
Hears Cora's faint call for help, quickly looks around to locate her, and swims with Michaels toward the indicated area.
Initially does not see Cora immediately but continues searching attentively, eventually spots her in the chasm and signals to Michaels.
Urgently warns Michaels to get back in the sub to avoid danger.
Races to reach Cora before the antibodies do and works desperately to free her.
Sees Cora in danger and immediately commands Michaels to get back in the sub and swims rapidly to help her.
Works desperately and skillfully to free Cora from the strands amid increasing threat of antibodies.
Struggles to get Cora's Breather Pack loose and helps her extricate herself from strands, acting under urgency and stress.
Holds exhausted Cora with one arm while swimming, supporting her despite his own fatigue.
Manages to free Cora from entangled strands and helps her swim upward despite exhaustion and danger.
Stays calm and alert at the ventral hatch, awaiting the right moment while protecting Cora.
Does not panic despite red warning light and pursuing antibodies.
Thrusts Cora through the door ahead of himself to protect her from the antibodies attack.
Struggles with all his strength to close and lock the door against the attacking antibodies, trying to protect both of them.
Attempts to help Cora loosen the coils constricting her despite the limited space and difficulty.
Drags Cora out of the escape hatch and joins frantic effort to free her from deadly coils.
Persistently pulls at the crystalline coils constraining Cora despite initial failure.
Joins in the combined effort to break the antibody coils after others begin to break them.
Reacts appropriately to complexity of chart, checks progress with glance at Minute Recorder.
Asks a relevant question about the source of light, showing observation skills.
Tells Cora there is no need to get up, showing consideration for her condition.
Responds to Cora's thanks with a modest, somewhat detached remark 'That's what they pay me for.'
Responds with a smile and light sarcasm about being under suspicion, indicating a level of openness and mild humor.
Engages in an informal, somewhat playful exchange about surveillance and mistrust, showing some degree of interpersonal ease.
Does not directly challenge or defend Dr. Duval but accepts the suspicion with light irony.
Reassures Cora about her condition and maintains professionalism; calmly responds to Cora's suspicion about his true role, showing awareness and subtle confidence.
Acknowledges being suspected to monitor Dr. Duval but does not show frustration or confusion; engages in the situation with composed humor and understanding.
Acknowledges the effect of love on perspective in a candid way to Cora.
Silently observes the tense confrontation without intervening.
Notes the disagreement and tension between Duval and Michaels and recognizes it as trouble, showing situational awareness.
Makes a somewhat ambiguous comment about perspective (‘Depends on which end of the telescope you look through.’) that indicates understanding of subjective viewpoints.
Engages thoughtfully and poetically in the conversation, demonstrating intellectual reflection.
Responds with meaningful contributions amidst complex scientific and philosophical discussion.
Does not interrupt or contradict experts like Duval or Michaels; remains composed and participatory.
Questions Michaels about consequences of overstaying and speed of travel, indicating concern for safety and procedure.
Disobeys direct orders by turning off controls and stopping the sub, preventing progress toward the Removal Point.
Questions the skipper about the consequences of overstaying and how long it will take to get to the removal point, showing situational awareness and critical thinking.
Acts quickly to disable controls and stop the sub from advancing into danger, demonstrating decisiveness and technical skill.
Takes charge to get the laser despite opposition, enables Duval and Cora to attempt a rescue.
Disregards Michaels' authority and warnings about mission danger.
Expresses doubt about Michaels' accusation and refuses to accept a simplistic explanation, showing trust in Duval's character.
Offers to go out and help despite the danger, showing willingness to support and assist others.
Glances at his wristwatch while checking on the operation progress, indicating concern and attentiveness toward the ongoing procedure.
Puts on his Breather Pack promptly when the Escape Hatch is being flooded.
Questions Michaels' accusation against Duval based on past experience with fanatics, showing judgment and calmness.
Decides to go out and help despite potential danger, demonstrating initiative and confidence.
Glances at minute recorder confirming time limits before proceeding, showing awareness of time constraints and procedural adherence.
Closes the Escape Hatch door and responds calmly to surroundings, indicating focus under pressure.
Checks his wristwatch while swimming toward Duval and Cora, monitoring time carefully.
Glances at his wrist watch and acknowledges the dire situation with 'Doctor, we've just about had it.'
Glances at his wrist watch and assesses the situation calmly, indicating awareness of time and urgency.
Does not immediately intervene or react strongly to the escalating crisis around the Escape Hatch.
Glances at wrist watch, urges team to hurry ('Every second counts now.')
Gets an idea to use the laser, takes initiative to grab it and lead the way with Cora supporting him
Recognizes urgency as electrical impulses race along the nerve and insists they must get back quickly; shows situational awareness and time management.
Responds quickly to unexpected danger by taking initiative to grab the laser and lead an interception with Cora following; demonstrates leadership and decisive action.
Recognizes that the ship is critically damaged and immediately proposes to exit on their own, showing situational awareness and pragmatic decision-making.
Asks if there is a quick way out, indicating proactive problem-solving without hesitation.
Stops Duval from rushing into danger and assesses the threat first.
Commands Duval and Cora to hold position and hold off the white corpuscles, taking the lead and responsibility himself.
Stops Duval from rushing forward impulsively, indicating cautious assessment of the situation.
Hands the laser to Duval and gives clear orders to hold off the threat, demonstrating leadership and tactical thinking.
Swims toward the threat himself, taking initiative to confront it personally.
Quickly navigates a narrow flooded area and grabs two Breather Packs on the way, showing situational awareness and resourcefulness.
Hurries to help Owens and Michaels; quickly assists Owens to regain consciousness; tries desperately to free Michaels from the Bubble.
Realizes Michaels has been sabotaging the mission but remains focused on rescue efforts.
Quickly acts to help Owens regain consciousness and equips him with a Breather Pack while realizing Michaels is the saboteur.
Attempts with all his strength to free Michaels from the steel arm but fails.
Makes a final desperate effort to free Michaels as the Bubble is being dissolved and the White Corpuscle engulfs Michaels.
Immediately suggests an alternative escape route through the Lab Section after confirming Michaels' fate.
Follows Owens carefully through a cramped area, indicating willingness to proceed cautiously in dangerous conditions.
Is grasped and engulfed by the White Corpuscle and struggles without apparent success to free himself.
Swims quickly toward teammates after being rescued, showing presence of mind and urgency.
Expresses frustration about not finding a quick way out, indicating potential lack of preparation or situational awareness.
Supports Cora by putting an arm around her waist to help her keep pace despite her fatigue.
Moves immediately to Benes and greets him warmly, extending hand and showing concern.
Moves immediately to Benes and engages warmly and confidently, showing social and professional aptitude.
Expresses concern and inquiries promptly upon learning critical information (Benes' memory loss).
Says goodbye to Benes warmly, acknowledging the experience of knowing him.
Quickly helps Owens up and hustles him to the hospital after their accident, showing concern for others' well-being.
Politely says goodbye to Mr. Benes, showing social awareness and composure.
Seemingly calmly handles the aftermath of a scooter crash, quickly getting up and helping Owens despite holding the side of his head.
Does not explicitly show medical knowledge or decision-making after potential head injury, but acts quickly to get Owens to the hospital.
Insists that neither he nor Owens are hurt and refuses help despite obvious concern from others.
Denies being hurt despite evidence he may be impaired; insists he and Owens are fine while driving recklessly at top speed and bypassing stopped traffic in the wrong lane.
